content.webTitle: Sambas, Brazukas and other curios: Spotter's guide to the World Cup draw

fields.headline: Sambas, Brazukas and other curios: Spotter's guide to the World Cup draw
fields.bodyText: 1 Man in gloves carries World Cup trophy into auditorium, handling it like it was sculpted out of angel-wing feathers by Michelangelo 2 Presenting duo Fernanda Lima and Rodrigo Hilbert split on whether it should be Bosnia-HerzeGOVina or Bosnia-HerzegovINA 3 A samba band, playing several different but complementary rhythms to produce a cohesive whole, used to illustrate official Brazil 2014™ slogan "All in One Rhythm" 4 Michel Platini looks visibly offended by the hip-hop stylings of Emicida 5 A scarlet macaw, a monkey in a jungle and a tapir all appear in Amazonian highlights package 6 Several from-the-air shots of high-tech stadia glinting in sunlight. No shots of half-completed stadia glinting in the torchlight of outraged protesters 7 Scattered Brazukas – the official World Cup ball – coincidentally left with Adidas logo facing the camera 8 Audience member wearing headphones and listening to live translation of the event chuckles for no apparent reason 9 Representative of Pot Four European FA punches air and howls in celebration after being paired with Switzerland and Algeria 10 An old player nobody's heard of who won something in 1950 given standing ovation by audience not sure what else to do 11 As the presenters cue up yet another dance routine you double-check to make sure you're on the right channel and not watching an elaborate live satire 12 English speaker unaware that "brazuka" is a local slang term for "Brazilian" makes inappropriate-in-the-circumstances rocket-launcher mime 13 Procedure for dealing with additional European team in Pot Four which needs to be moved into Pot Two and then drawn against a side in Pot One which has been moved to Pot X explained at length to widespread quizzical looks among audience
